/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Hi Maciej,

from nvme-disconnect man page:
       Disconnects and removes one or more existing NVMe over Fabrics controllers. If the --nqn option is specified all controllers connecting to the
       Subsystem identified by subnqn will be removed. If the --device option is specified the controller specified by the --device option will be
       removed.

We cannot disconnect an individual disk with the command - only whole nqn subsystems or controllers. Also the device should just disappear once storage system "unmaps"/"unbinds" the disk from the host. Still I believe such situations with ghost volumes can happen (broken session?). It's only safe to delete controller or subsystem when there are no volumes managed by them for the host.

Vladislav I just noticed your patch, that removes disconnect command. We should still have disconnect command to avoid ghost drivers on initiator side. I think we could disconnect using -d <device> instead using nqn - let me know what do you think about it.

You are right. We should probably track the number of volumes within a controller and disconnect controller if all volumes were removed, but controller still exists in the system (broken session case). I will prepare patch for that if you agree that this would be sufficient solution.
Could you not make this configurable and hardcode 15s?

ovsdbapp/schema/ovn_northbound/commands..message: nit: It would be safe to default addresses=(), since a tuple is immutable to avoid having to do addresses or [].

In the case that maybe someone passed a tuple, we'd end up with a list containing a tuple. I find python's lack of built-in "it's an iterable, but it's not a string or bytes" irritating, but maybe something like:

 if not(isinstance(collections.abc.Iterable) and not isinstance((str, bytes)):

is what we need here? (which would make a good utils function). Or maybe just:

 if isinstance(addresses, (str, bytes)): addresses = [addresses]?

Thoughts?

Instead of completely overwriting the list with the existing + appended values, I think you should be able to use Row.addvalue() to just send the mutations. Otherwise, this would need a Row.verify() call to ensure that the value hadn't been changed on the db before our "append" might actually overwrite existing data.

import-stx.message: Why the default value is 8, do you have any reference?
We can also see it at build-tools/build-srpms-parallel script in the root repo for centos building.

For background, In centos build, or first set of build servers were 32 core & 128 GB ram, and out goal was to support 4 concurrent builds with minimal contention for resources.  32/4 = 8

So 8 was used for srpm build phase which is usually serial.

The rpm build phase used 4, not 8, builders.  3 out of 4 builders were ramdisk based (~8GB), to reduce the io bottleneck.  128GB - (4x3x8GB) = 32GB ram for all other purposes.  Seemed to work well to push our servers hard without breaking them.

In Centos, a 'worker' represents a package to be built in parallel with other packages, not a CPU.  Each worker had access to all CPU's.  So if all package use parallel build, then ABSOLUTE_MAX_WORKERS represented the worst case number of R status threads per CPU.  Again I used 4 not 8 for the bulk of the package build.  8 was only used for the SRPM build which was serial.

IF your worker represents a dedicated cpu, you might go with NUM_CPU's / 4 in a shared machine, and just NUM_CPU's on a private machine.  You can try to detect share machines by looking for number of unique logged in userid's.  You could even go with NUM_CPU's / NUM_USERS ... but I'd suggest that's too pessimistic as many users are just working with code and not actually building.

Probably simplest to just replace 'WORKERS' with 'CPUS' in your variable names for now.  Limiting Minikube's resources makes sense.  We can continue to tinker with how the resources are allocated in future.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Jia, please add the unit tests to your review when you include the commit message changes requested by Bob.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Link to LKML via Lore when possible, so change to

https://lore.kernel.org/all/00000000000080403805c6ef586d@google.com/
You should put the upstream info into the header of the patch itself.  I also notice that this isn't the only kernel patch from some upstream source missing such info eg. rt kernel patch 9.

The call trace is from a WARN_ONCE and matching it to the syzkaller-bugs report is a stretch at best. I understand you have been asked to apply this bug in the hopes that it will fix the bug report but I am not a fan of wishful thinking.

I suspect this thread is more relevant to this issue at hand

https://lore.kernel.org/all/20210917211148.GU4156@paulmck-ThinkPad-P17-Gen-1/#t

> I've been researching some RCU warnings we see that lead
> to full lockups with longterm 5.x kernels.
> 
> Basically the rcu_advance_cbs() == true warning in
> rcu_advance_cbs_nowake() is firing then everything eventually
> gets stuck on RCU synchronization because the GP thread stays
> asleep while rcu_state.gp_flags & 1 == 1 (this is a bunch
> of nohz_full cpus)

Which maps exactly on to the issue report

"WARNING: CPU: 35 PID: 2743975 at kernel/rcu/tree.c:1589 rcu_advance_cbs_nowake+0x78/0x80" followed by full lockups.

I know management is pushing for a quick fix, but attempting to merge something with the smallest thread of being a fix is just going to make things take longer. Please review the thread I point out above and the associated patches, I think this is the direction we need to go to have any success.

You may want to be a bit more descriptive with the commit's subject line. Maybe the following would be an improvement?

```
Avoid RCU-related unexpected reboot
```

Others may have better suggestions.
Ack

Minor suggestion:

```
We encountered an unexpected system reboot during a stress test, and based on the kernel warning backtrace, it looks like a race condition in the RCU subsystem caused this issue.

It is similar to the issue reported at https://lore.kernel.org/all/20210917211148.GU4156@paulmck-ThinkPad-P17-Gen-1/#t

...
```
Thank you Vefa for the comments improved.

It looks like the second patch ("EXP rcu: Tighten rcu_advance_cbs_nowake() checks") has been dropped from mainline *perhaps* because it was a debugging patch:

```
$ git show -s 1a792b5907
commit 1a792b59071b697defd4ccdc8b951cce49de9d2f
Author: Paul E. McKenney <paulmck@kernel.org>
Date:   Fri Sep 17 15:04:48 2021 -0700

    EXP rcu: Tighten rcu_advance_cbs_nowake() checks
    
    This is an experimental shot-in-the-dark debugging patch.
    
    Signed-off-by: Paul E. McKenney <paulmck@kernel.org>

$ git describe --contains 1a792b5907
next-20210927~38^2~7

$ git log --oneline --grep 'EXP rcu: Tighten rcu_advance_cbs_nowake() checks' v5.14..next-20210927
1a792b59071b EXP rcu: Tighten rcu_advance_cbs_nowake() checks

$ git log --oneline --grep 'EXP rcu: Tighten rcu_advance_cbs_nowake() checks' v5.14..next-20210928
# No output

$ git describe --match='v5*' --contains 1a792b5907
fatal: cannot describe '1a792b59071b697defd4ccdc8b951cce49de9d2f'
```

You may want to drop that patch.

The other patch "rcu: Mark accesses to rcu_state.n_force_qs" has been committed for v5.16:

```
$ git show -s --oneline 2431774f04
2431774f04d1 rcu: Mark accesses to rcu_state.n_force_qs

$ git describe --match='v5*' --contains 2431774f04
v5.16-rc1~163^2~16
```

Please update the commit message to reflect these. Thanks!

Hello all,

Jiping pointed out that the patch was not dropped, and after a chat session and some more digging on my end, we found that the patch titled "EXP rcu: Tighten rcu_advance_cbs_nowake() checks" was reworked into the following commit:

https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/paulmck/linux-rcu.git/commit/?h=rcu/next&id=325a2030b90376d179a129794e2fae2b24d73923

Jiping, if everyone agrees, please use this patch instead of the earlier version of the patch. Thanks for your patience with me!

Mark and Jim, what do you think of pulling in this patch from linux-next? It is not yet in mainline (i.e., Linus's tree).

Thanks Vefa and Jiping for digging into this and finding the later refined patch. I am fine with pulling this in from linux-next, especially given that it is coming from PaulM.
You may want to add a bit more detailed information about the nature of the tests carried out by the colleagues in the test team. For example, did they run a stress test? Please add more details.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
After looking at this a bit more, I'm wondering whether it would be better to create a new scheduler, maybe called StaticScheduler, that schedules speakers to agents only based on what it is being told via the API. That would require some work to refactor a couple of things, but in the end I think it could even become the default scheduler and we could possibly deprecate the others.

Is there any use case for setting one of the two new variables but not the other?

The more I look the more broken this whole automatic scheduling seems to me. So I'll go ahead with doing a static option and possibly even deprecating the other ones unless someone explains their use case to me.
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-dynamic-routing/+/815265 for StaticScheduler is merged now, could you please check if that covers your usecase?
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-dynamic-routing/+/815265 is my alternative approach, which I think is both easier and cleaner
I believe that StaticScheduler is a very nice and clean approach, and I would abandon my change in favor of it.
I have tested StaticScheduler, it works perfectly for me. Thanks!

neutron_dynamic_routing/db/bgp_dragentsc.message: this is inline with e.g. similar options for L3 agent https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/6d8e830859cd4ac9708701b8e344fdc68cbcaebb/neutron/conf/db/l3_agentschedulers_db.py#L27 which is good IMO

maybe You could name this one like "bgp_speaker_auto_schedule" to also make it inline with L3 agent's config option https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/6d8e830859cd4ac9708701b8e344fdc68cbcaebb/neutron/conf/db/l3_agentschedulers_db.py#L25 ?

This is one of the reasons for the observed bug. reschedule_resources_from_down_agents() finds an agent that is down, but doesn't pass the ID of the down agent into this function. Instead, it removes the BGP speaker from the first agent that it discovers, which is simply wrong in case e.g. the second agent goes down.
This check then prevents the speaker from being scheduled to the agent that it was just removed from, leaving it only scheduled to the down agent (unless there are more than two agents).

How is the status 0 handled differently from status 160.
They seem to resolve to the same enabled-active state.
What is the value of handling 160 as this update does nothing with it.

0 and 160 are 2 possible return value from "openldap status". SM does not handle the warning status of 160 (approaching to limit), so to SM it is equivalent to a 0 as "success". a non 0 return code needs to be specified otherwise it will be treated as failure.
It appears 'success' is appropriate here in the degraded case - as per drbd SERVICE_ACTION_RESULTS above.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Did you verify if openstack is acessible in this TC? I just want to be sure that enabling https on the platform will not generate a situation where openstack tries to use an unexisting openstack_ssl. You would have to re-apply openstack after enabling https to make sure the overrides are not being messed up with.

The Openstack reapply failing because there is no openstack_ssl is a problem that already exists today. The objective of this change is to allow the configuration of Openstack certificate to avoid this reapply error, because in the current implementation the user has no choice but to set "https_enabled=True", wait reapply error, install openstack_ssl and then fix the apply. Also, it's not clear how should be the behavior of Openstack reapply regarding the values of "https_enabled" combined with presence/absence of openstack_ssl (maybe with the creation of "openstack_https_enabled" system parameter). I think that this will be treated in another issue.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Something to consider:
Platform https is allowed to be enabled even there is no SSL cert is installed (since sysinv will generate a self-signed cert for it). Enabling platform https will trigger openstack to automatically re-apply to enable https as well. But if there is no openstack cert available at the time, openstack re-apply will fail. So maybe adding a checking to prevent https enabling if openstack is not available and fail the enabling earlier. Otherwise, this requirement needs to be documented.

Yes, I think it is a valid scenario that platform https is enabled while openstack is not. I agree, probably openstack shouldn't auto reapply until 1. platform https is enabled and 2. openstack certs present, and the change will be in openstack app.

Andy, I understood what you are proposing, but wouldn't it be a valid scenario having HTTPS enabled for StarlingX REST API application endpoints (Keystone, Barbican, StarlingX) and StarlingX platform Horizon GUI, while having Openstack not using HTTPS (using HTTP in this case)? If it's a valid scenario, then having "https_enable=True" and no "openstack" cert present should be ok, and the Openstack reapply should not fail, as it should continue using HTTP. In this case, the code of Openstack reapply should be changed instead.

to get python version of a switch statemnt for that but 3.7 has some nice help methods for asyncio and other lib feature that while not relevent to nova right now might be relevent to some.

well, I am just saying we to be a little flexible which is what testing runtime means.

Just a note: it will be rare that we will introduce any code which is compatible for py3.8 and not with py3.6 but there are possibility.

> Bumping this will make nova un-installable on py3.6, right.

It will, yes.

> I think the intent of adding 'python_requires = >=3.6' was to make it py3-only when we dropped the py2.7 support. I will say we keep it as it is until we bump it to py4 or a higher version of py3 (say py 3.20) so that people can keep installing nova in py3.6. Dropping test of py3.6 is that 'we do not guarantee that it works as we dropped the testing, but if it works in your env then it is ok.'

This does seem like a "gentler" approach, but the risk of this is that we're forcing users to read documentation to determine support instead of just having their tooling (pip or whatever) do the right thing automatically. We explicitly don't support Python 3.6 so I don't think we want anyone trying to install with this combination since it'll only result in bug reports. This isn't a hill I'm going to die on, but it does seem like something we should at least consider doing (and maybe even something worth discussing on openstack-discuss. In fact, I'll start a thread)

PS: I don't think we'll make it anywhere near 3.20 or 4.0 before we need to bump this. If nothing else, other dependencies will have dropped Python 3.6 support or we'll have started using syntax that's specific to Python 3.7 or later. If it's not tested, it's broken.

I'm somewhat impressed that ansible is able to find this file relative to the gitea-lb role using relative paths from within the haproxy role. This is something that puppet has struggled with in the past.

That said I wonder if we shouldn't try to qualify the haproxy.cfg.j2 path a bit more in gitea-lb.

I think this is intentional that it looks at the path of the parent role (https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbook_pathing.html#the-magic-of-local-paths).

However, I agree it is quite magic.  I think the best thing would be to more explicitly name the template (prefix with gitea-) so that we don't ever have two generically named haproxy.cfg.j2 files we need to decide between
We weren't doing it before but maybe we should set ownership and mode on this file? I think it is owner: 1000 group: 1000 and mode: 0644?
Since this is a directory it should be 0755

doc/source/reference/jobs.rst.message:
This is a little confusing to me. We appear to construct data like:

  { 'path': {'name': 'foo', 'checkout': 'bar', 'commit': '123467'} }

but the statement above doesn't really convey that. Maybe update this line to say:

  The key is the path and each value is another dict with the following key value pairs.

I feel like this paragraph may need a bit more detail now that we are exposing these underlying details to users. I know I personally have to go dig in and figure it all out again when it comes up.

In particular I think it is important to note that we only add these aliases to the role_path to avoid conflicts.

We actually don't take a position on conflicts.  Since we're adding things to the role path, we can add as many "foo" roles as we want, and ansible will just take the first one in the path.  The symlinks allow us to either avoid or create conflicts (we can rename our second "foo" to "bar" or our "bar" to be a second "foo").  But mostly, they let us say that the bare role repo "ansible-role-foo" is "foo".

I'll add a sentence saying that the symlinks allow us to provide the role path to ansible with the correct name.

Really it all comes down to this sentence: https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul/reference/job_def.html#attr-job.roles.name

 > 
 > Though I'm also not really sure how nova behaves here, does it
 > really only store the name a server was created with and not the
 > id? Why does then the server-create API call for a flavorRef with
 > an id?

Nova only returns the name of the flavor but not the id of the flavor since 2.47. The API ref states:

  flavor.id body string
	
  The ID of the flavor. While people often make 
  this look like an int, this is really a string.

  Available until version 2.46


When the server is created nova copies the flavor information into the instance object. This way the lifetime of the flavor is disconnected from the lifetime of the server. The server can potentially outlive the flavor and nova still know what resources was requested originally for the server.

Nova does not store the flavor id as it has no use in nova as nova will never look up that flavor any more as the flavor information is copied into the instance.
I would make this comparison "< 2.47", except using one character less, it also shows the version that changed this behaviour.

Re: the unit test failures, you will need to update the FakeServer method [1] to populate a sample 'original_name' attribute for flavors so that it reflects reality for >= 2.47 [2].

You will want to add something like this in FakeServer. create_one_server:

 version = self.app.client_manager.compute.api_version
 if version >= api_versions.APIVersion('2.47'):
      server_info['flavor']['original_name'] = 'flavor-name-' + uuid.uuid4().hex

On the functional test front, it looks like we're already covered as some tests run with microversion >= 2.47 for example [3].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/python-openstackclient/blob/8387b114e38f21922967ba982bb1a25289fdb3ab/openstackclient/tests/unit/compute/v2/fakes.py#L607-L609
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=list-servers-detailed-detail#list-servers
[3] https://github.com/openstack/python-openstackclient/blob/8387b114e38f21922967ba982bb1a25289fdb3ab/openstackclient/tests/functional/compute/v2/test_server.py#L127
I tackled this by just splitting the test class in two - pre- and post-v2.47 - and modifying self.attrs. Hopefully that works for people

Ah, comment on PS8: "Also, I'd rather we called the column 'Original Flavor Name' or similar, to distinguish it from the actual flavor since things could be different now."

I don't really agree with this ^, it seems confusing IMHO to not just say it's the "Flavor Name". "Original Flavor" to me implies that this is the first flavor the instance was ever created with and if it's been resized since, this value isn't reflecting the current flavor when the instance flavor is in fact updated after a resize finishes.

Besides that, I think since all of the flavor details are embedded in the instance anyway, we need not be as concerned about whether the flavor name still maps to a specific combo of vcpus/memory_mb/disk_gb/extra_specs because all of data is available independently on the instance.

FWIW, I agree with the fact we shouldn't change the name itself from what we had before.

Changing the column title would also let the microversion bubbling up to the client, while we prefer to be conservative in case we don't need to change the behaviour.

I agree with Sylvain and Mel here - the embedded flavor information that we're displaying here is what's currently true for the instance. If we introduce the "original" wording in there, it could lead to confusion by, for example, implying that there's been a resize or something.

I took the liberty of rebasing the patch to fix the merge conflicts, and addressing this feedback.

Aside: I see in the API this is called original_name when it was added:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/434514/16/nova/api/openstack/compute/views/servers.py#255

but TBH I don't understand why "original_name" was chosen rather than "name". I would guess the idea was that what's stored in the server represented the flavor's "original" name in the case that the flavor name was changed later. But, our API doesn't allow a flavor's name to be changed ... you can only update a flavor's "description", else you have to delete and recreate the flavor, which makes it a different flavor. So again the term "original name" is confusing, at least to me.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Hi fellow reviewers, if you have some time, please check this patch.

This can be implemented inside a ovs-agent extension without changing any existing code in ovs_neutron_agent and rpc. Something similart to the port forwarding implementation:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/533850/35/neutron/agent/l3/extensions/port_forwarding.py#135

Hey Yulong, port forwarding is an l3 agent extension. For l2 agent extension it's interface is not quite suitable here as it's about port's updates. Here we need to handle new resource updates: Local IP Association. It allows to avoid overload port related logic (which is already quite overloaded). Another benefit is that nothing needs to be configured on agent side - if local ip service is not enabled on the server - no local ip updates will be issued.

Port forwarding is an example that can handle resource notifications. I should use L2 agent extension to explain the approach. Ovs-agent has similar extensions, like log [1] and qos [2]. Just adds the new ovo resource to the list [3], then all you need is to receive the update event. No extra changes for RPC files and No new callback methods for ovs-agent main code. So again, port forwarding implementation is a really good example.

This is a new feature for ovs-agent, so it should be configurable as an agent extension. New features are usually buggy, we can disable it by default. So a service plugin in neutron-server side, and an agent extension in agent side. That's we had done for many new features, such as port forwarding, log, qos.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/services/logapi/agent/log_extension.py#L82
[2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/agent/l2/extensions/qos.py#L196
[3] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/api/rpc/callbacks/resources.py#L41
Thanks Yulong, I'm checking if agent extension can cover all needed changes for local ip functioning. I'll come back with results later

One little thing, one same topic is fine to track all related patches. This features now have too many patch topics. I will change all these feature related patches with topic "local_ip" which is consistent with the spec: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-specs/+/797798. So everytime new patch set uploaded, please do not forget to update the topic.
Yulong, please check latest version. I agree it looks more clean now, thanks!
Thanks for updating, yes, it looks better now. Do not forget to add test cases. 😊
Sorry, there are 2 patches which have "bug/1930200". Since spec is not the real working code, so topic "bug/1930200" should be fine to trace all code.

The entire implementation order should be:
1. neutron-server side (API/DB/plugin) works with some resource notification changes
2. "Add Local IP L2 extension flows" which only added helper functions on br-int
3. "Add Local IP L2 extension" which add the whole extension, the new extension will use the flow functions on br-int
4. policy works
5. test works
...

Hi Yulong. In implementation I tend to stick to the following principle: only add code that is needed in current patch. This makes review easier IMO - you don't need to open other patches to figure out how this code will be used. Thus I'd prefer to stay with current order: 

 1) API/DB patch only has code needed for API/DB to work
 2) Agent extension patch adds mechanism for server <-> agent communication on Local IPs
 3) Agent flows patch: fills agent extension with actual flows logic.

Please share your opinion, what are major drawbacks with this approach? Is it a blocking issue?
Commit message was updated to better explain my intent of this patch chain.

api-ref/source/v3/volumes-v3-types.inc.message:
I think we don't need to discuss __DEFAULT__ here, because if that's your default, then that's your default.  But I think you could do something like this for the text in this section:

  Shows details for the default volume type, that is, the volume type that
  will be used in the `Create a volume`_ request if you do not specify one.
  This could be one of the following:
  
  - Your project's default volume type *(since microversion 3.62)*
  - The installation's default volume type as configured by the operator
  - A "Not Found" response (only in pre-Train versions of the
    Block Storage service; a configured default volume type has been
    required since the Train release)

In the third point i think it's better to mention the current response which is a 500 Internal Server Error response if the default volume type is not configured properly (raised by VolumeTypeDefaultMisconfiguredError)[1]

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/volume/volume_types.py#L226-L227

Maybe add:

  *Note to operators:* Since the Train release, untyped volumes are
  not allowed, and a configured default volume type is required in each
  deployment.  An attempt to delete the configured default volume type
  will fail.

How about this instead:

  Lists the available volume types.
  
  To determine which of these is the default type that will be used if you
  do not specify one in the `Create a volume`_ request, use the
  `Show default volume type`_ request.
  
  *Note to users:* There may be a volume type named ``__DEFAULT__`` in the
  list.  Confusingly, it may not be your default volume type.  To create a
  volume of *your* default volume type, simply omit the ``volume_type``
  parameter in your `Create a volume`_ request.
  
  *Note to operators:* The ``__DEFAULT__`` volume type was introduced in
  the Train release as a placeholder to prevent the creation of untyped
  volumes.  Under the proper conditions, it may be removed from your
  deployment.  Consult the `Cinder Administration Guide
  <https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/admin/index.html>`_
  for details.

In *Note to users:*, i think we don't want to promote end users to prefer the default over providing their volume types in request but rather default types are a fail safe mechanism to avoid creating volumes into unwanted backends (decided by scheduler)
I've updated the text, let me know what you think?

In *Note to operators:*, I'm not sure the admin docs tell a lot about default types and conditions to remove __DEFAULT__, i think [1] would be a better reference?

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/cinder/train.html#other-notes

You make a good point about this text.  But since the "This" at line 311 is referring to the volume type, this third point really shouldn't be here.  I suggest that we add 404 and 500 to the "Response codes" section below, and since we don't have control over the text that gets displayed there, let's add something like the following, probably after "Response codes" but before "Request":


  Error conditions
  ----------------
  
  It is only possible to receive a 404 (Not Found) response in pre-Train
  versions of the Block Storage service, as a configured default volume
  type has been required since the Train release.
  
  If you receive a 500 (Internal Error Response), then the default volume
  type has not been configured correctly by the operator.  Please contact
  your cloud provider.
  
  * When the default volume type is misconfigured, requests to
    `Create a volume`_ that do not include a volume type will
    fail.
  * The workaround is to include a volume type in your request.  You
    can `List all volume types`_ to determine a volume type to use.

You make a good point.  Maybe say something like

  Do not use this volume type in a `Create a volume`_ request.  If you
  wish to create a volume of *your* default volume type, simply omit the
  ``volume_type`` parameter in your `Create a volume`_ request.

Not sure I really liket that, though.  Hopefully some other reviewer will have a good idea about how to make this point.

I think it's too restrictive to say 'not to use this type'. There might be a case where operator has used the __DEFAULT__ for a case where the default_volume_type is different and the user needs to use __DEFAULT__ to create volumes in a specific backend. I've slightly updated the text. let me know what you think.
Good point about my suggestion being too restrictive.  I like what you came up with much better!

You're right that there's not much currently in the admin docs.  They need to be updated because we can't really expect someone installing Xena to read all previous release notes ... they expect that the Xena docs tell them what they need to know.  So I think we should link to the admin docs here, but put up another patch copying the content from the release notes to the admin docs.  (What you have here is fine short-term, though.  You can change this reference as part of the patch that updates/creates the admin doc about volume types.)
Ack, i will update in a followup patch where i will add the admin documentation as well for the same. Thanks.

api-ref/source/v3/volumes-v3-volumes.inc.message:
Instead of hiding this down here, I suggest adding a new paragraph after line 166:

  Since the Train release, every volume must have a volume type.  It
  is **optional** to specify a volume type as part of your `Create a
  volume` request.  If you do not specify one, a default volume type
  will be supplied for you.  This type may vary according to what
  project you are in and how the operator has configured the Block
  Storage service.  Use the `Show default volume type`_ request to
  determine your effective default volume type.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: That's a cryptic message. ;) But I agree, this is not the way forward and tagging doesn't seem to be so much of an issue if we're not bashing Neutron with concurrent bulk port requests.

This is a bit risky, as adding the ports to the trunk may take some time (as well as fail), delaying the tagging could lead to leaks. I think adding the ports to the trunks is actually the most expensive call (as it requires installation of flows). Any kuryr-controller crash in between those actions (creation of ports and complete attachment to the trunk) would lead to orphan resources

If addition to the trunk fail, the ports are deleted right after. For some reason adding tags seems to be taking more time than adding to the trunk some times, it needs to go over all Ports. Good point on the controller restart while adding to the trunk, I will re-evaluate

doc/source/install/get-started-block-sto.message:
I suggest adding a heading here (because I'm going to suggest adding another one below):

  Components
  ----------

I suggest adding a heading here and some more details to make this clear to operators.  Something like:

  The default volume type
  -----------------------
  
  Since the Train release, it is required that each volume must have a
  *volume type*, and thus the required configuration option
  ``default_volume_type`` must have a value.  A system-defined volume type
  named ``__DEFAULT__`` is created in the database during installation and
  is the default value of the ``default_volume_type`` configuration option.
  
  You (or your deployment tool) may wish to have a different volume type that
  is more suitable for your particular installation as the default type.
  This can be accomplished by creating the volume type you want using the
  Block Storage API, and then setting that volume type as the value for
  the configuration option.  (The latter operation, of course, cannot be
  done via the Block Storage API.)
  
  The system defined ``__DEFAULT__`` volume type is a regular volume type
  that may be updated or deleted.  There is nothing special about it.  It only
  exists because there must always be at least one volume type in a cinder
  deployment, and before the Block Storage API comes up, there is no way for
  there to be a volume type unless the system creates it.
  
  Given that since the Victoria release it is possible to set a default
  volume type for any project, having a volume type named ``__DEFAULT__``
  in your deployment may be confusing to your users, leading them to
  specifically request ``__DEFAULT__`` when creating a volume instead of
  simply using the default volume type that you have configured for the
  system or for their project.
  
  If you don't wish to use the ``__DEFAULT__`` type, you may delete it.  The
  Block Storage API will prevent deletion under these circumstances:
  
  * If ``__DEFAULT__`` is the value of the ``default_volume_type`` configuration
    option then it cannot be deleted.  The solution is to make a different
    volume type the value of that configuration option.
  * If there are volumes in the deployment of the ``__DEFAULT__`` type, then
    it cannot be deleted.  The solution is to retype those volumes to some
    other appropriate volume type.
(BTW, the pep8 failure was that there wasn't a newline at end of the file, so watch for that when you update your patch.)

Thanks for the detailed doc! I've changed the fourth paragraph a bit since default types are not something user requests but a fail safe mechanism when no type is provided by the user.
(Also thanks for pointing out the pep8 failure)

What you say here is correct, but I think the source of https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1886632 was that users would do

  cinder type-list

see __DEFAULT__ in there, and then do

  cinder create --volume-type __DEFAULT__ 22

which would mean that the actually configured default type was not being used to create the requested volume.  It's kind of an obvious point, but I think it's worth pointing out, so that operators realize the implications of not deleting __DEFAULT__.

I'm not too sure as i couldn't find a similar reference in the reported bug when we are creating a volume with the __DEFAULT__ type. I see the intention there is to delete the __DEFAULT__ when we already have another default configured via default_volume_type.
Having said that, I understand your point and it's no harm providing extra information so i will update the text to reflect that as well.
You are correct, it's not explicitly stated in the bug.  I was just imagining this was what the problem was! Thanks for making the update, though, I think it's an improvement.
